narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture, optional attendance, live midterm and final
Office hours with Karan on Friday
None
Lecture recordings were posted online

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Classical Mechanics
Basically an elaboration of intro physics plus the following: calculus of variations and Lagrangian dynamics, more on central force motion, special relativity.
I learned how to use the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formalisms to solve basic classical mechanics problems.
Thornton/Marion - Classical Dynamics of Particles and Systems. You learn everything in this book and nothing more.

Classical mechanics including newtonian mechanics, oscillations, gravity, calculus of variations, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics, central-force motion, dynamics systems of particles, noninertial reference frames, dynamics of rigid bodies, coupled oscillations,  and special relativity
I learned how the use the Lagrangian to solve problems. I found Noether's theorem to be the highlight of the course. I want to learn more about the calculus of variations, it is amazing.
I learned about classical mechanics, the Euler-Lagrange method, and pretty much all the stuff in PHYS 200 (plus special relativity) except faster and with Lagrangians.
A deeper understanding of classical mechanics than was provided in intro physics including Lagrangian Mechanics, Inertia Tensors, and Special Relativity.
General classical mechanics knowledge and physics problem solving strategies
I developed my physics skills with specific techniques and general physics problem solving intuition.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Psets are fair and professor is good.

Strengths: Many examples, Professor Baker is a kind person.

Weaknesses: PRIORITIES. This was my biggest complaint of the course. Many times, we would be re-learning topics from intro physics. When something newer or harder would arise, we would go through it very quickly, and not very much in depth, leaving this to the homework. For example, we learned all about how to calculate the inertia tensor, but not how to do rigid-body dynamics with it. Much time would be spent evaluating integrals that most people in the class knew how to do. The midterm and final were conceptual multiple-choice, and didn't really feel like an in-depth assessment of knowledge. I can't say I engaged very highly with the material, and my understanding of the upper-level topics is shaky at best. Professor Baker doesn't always answer questions very clearly. I would really liked to have seen more time spent on the Calculus of Variations/Lagrangian Dynamics, Central Force Motion, Rigid Body Dynamics, and Special Relativity sections.

They say you get out of it what you put into it, so if the problems and exams are quite easy, then you don't have to put a lot into it and so not much is gained. I think that was the main issue with this course. Even simply keeping the same number of problems on problem sets but picking more difficult ones from the textbook could improve this course. Even though it's a second course in classical mechanics, it felt more like a somewhat advanced first course.

Strengths: Material is comprehensively treated. Baker is a kind and well-motivated professor with a distinct old-school vibe. TAs and guest lecturers were good as well.

Weaknesses: Exam formats were somewhat unconventional - while I understand the intent of emulating the GRE, I would suggest that Prof. Baker look to non-multiple choice formats in the future.

Professor Baker is extremely nice and understanding. The assessments were meant to check your conceptual understanding of the physics and not too difficult and the problem sets were more calculation based. The material covered is extremely interesting if you like physics and you can immediately see how useful the Lagrangian is for physics Professor Baker also went through problems from the textbook during lecture which I found great for developing an understanding.

The whole entire course should be on the Lagrangian. The first week should be a rigorous mathematical look at the calculus of variations. The second week should be an introduction to the Lagrangian. The third week should be Noether's theorem. The rest of the course should be a deep dive into chapters 10-14. Non-inertial frames, Angular momentum, coupled oscillators and relativity are all great subjects that are almost completely new at the 400 level. Chapters 1-6 and chapter 8 are merely recaps of physics 260 (Girvin was a great professor). I understand that not everyone at the 400 level took 260 so maybe this means the class needs to be split into two. Even if this ideal cannot be achieved, covering less chapters in more depth is the way to go. The way the course is currently set up, each new topic felt like a review of high school and first year college physics.

The course tried to cover a lot of material in a relatively short amount of time. It might honestly be good to break it up a little (like maybe put special relativity in a separate class). But the things we did learn made physics life so much easier. I would like to see more support for the class (in terms of study halls and ULAs), however, because it felt like there was a huge dropoff between this and the introductory physics courses in those areas. I didn't really know whom to ask when I had trouble, and it was hard not to already know everyone from a previous physics course. (i.e. PHYS 200 students can DEFINITELY succeed in this class, but they need to work harder to find friends/work buddies because it felt like everyone was a PHYS 260-er who knew everything already.)
Professor Baker would occasionally delete all his whiteboard work which was funny, perhaps a 10 minute technology lesson from his daughter would suffice
This course was very well taught and the only weakness would probably be not being the most organized at times. Not many things I think that could be improved.
KEITH BAKER is a GIFT to humanity. Great professor, sweetest guy. He understands that most learning takes place doing the homework, so the exams are easy-medium difficulty. LOVE this prof.
Professor Baker really cares about physics and his students and made classes enjoyable. Sometimes they were a bit dry just reading off notes, though.
I thought this course was done very well. I think Dr. Baker was a very good professor and was able to convey the importance of material very well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I never felt like we struck a great balance between how much of the lecture should be typed and how much written out. The app we were using as a whiteboard wasn't the best. I'd recommend a powerpoint with major points typed and annotating in the details/proofs/examples.
I think having assessments be conceptual multiple choice and the problem sets as more calculation based was a good idea given the circumstances.

Prof Baker did a good job working around the difficulties posed by COVID. I would suggest always reading over notes (but go more slowly), than writing things out (it just takes too much time and we can go over the algebra in our free time).

This class could have been much improved if Professor Baker lectured like normal on a blackboard but had someone filming him. The trade-off with asynchronous lectures is that it is good in this subject to be able to ask questions, but hopefully adding office hours more regularly would help with that. The whiteboard/annotation features on Zoom caused much tsuris, making the lectures too fast or too slow depending on whether the professor showed us lecture notes or wrote them all out by hand. Also, the wifi was a bit patchy, and pre-recorded lectures would probably help with that.
All remote for me

I don't think this class could have been conducted better given the circumstances. Professor Baker was still getting used to the remote format so there were hiccups there but otherwise everything was great!
Recorded lectures and posted notes were very helpful

I thought the virtual lectures went well and thought that Dr. Baker was particularly conscious of the difficulties of the online setting with regards to online lecture engagement, which made the course a lot more doable I believe.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, interesting material and fair workload.
If you are a physics major you probably have to take it, but if you are looking for more physics exposure simply out of interest, I'm not sure this course is a particularly engaging option.
Probably not, but ultimately in depends on your preparation. If you don't have a strong background in classical mechanics, then it could be worth your while.
This is a good choice if you want a mid/high-level refresher of classical physics, or if you're interested in fulfilling the science requirement for the Math major.
Yes, this course is great for anyone interested in physics and is necessary for moving onto more complicated topics.
There was not much new content in the course. The Lagrangian is great but it is only featured in two classes.
I would recommend this course to another student. It was kind of tough without much course-based support, but at the end I felt a real sense of accomplishment.
Yes fo sho! If you an undergrad dont take physics 500, that mistake set me back a year
This class was great to follow intro physics and is a good class to take in the physics major so I would recommend this class to another student.
Probably; I might not recommend it to someone without previous physics courses at Yale
The course was not particularly difficult but Professor Baker is great, would recommend for a chill physics math class.
I would recommend this course. I found it very interesting and would especially recommend that they take this course with Dr. Baker.
